text: So I can't seem to figure this out...
I have a string say, "a\\nb" and I want this to become "a\nb".
I've tried all the following and none seem to work;

code:
>>> a
'a\\nb'
>>> a.replace("\\","\")
  File "<stdin>", line 1
    a.replace("\\","\")
                      ^
SyntaxError: EOL while scanning string literal
>>> a.replace("\\",r"\")
  File "<stdin>", line 1
    a.replace("\\",r"\")
                       ^
SyntaxError: EOL while scanning string literal
>>> a.replace("\\",r"\\")
'a\\\\nb'
>>> a.replace("\\","\\")
'a\\nb'

text: I really don't understand why the last one works, because this works fine:
Is there something I'm missing here?
EDIT I understand that \ is an escape character.
What I'm trying to do here is turn all \\n \\t etc.
and replace doesn't seem to be working the way I imagined it would.

code:
>>> a = "a\\nb"
>>> b = "a\nb"
>>> print a
a\nb
>>> print b
a
b
>>> a.replace("\\","\\")
'a\\nb'
>>> a.replace("\\\\","\\")
'a\\nb'

text: I want string a to look like string b.
But replace isn't replacing slashes like I thought it would.
